description:
Zygaena filipendulae, commonly known as the Six-spot Burnet, is a species of moth belonging to the family Zygaenidae. It is native to Europe and parts of Asia, and can be found in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, meadows, and woodland edges.

The Six-spot Burnet moth has a distinct appearance, with a bright red or orange body and six red or orange spots on its dark blue or black wings. The wingspan of the adult moth is typically between 30-40 millimeters. The larvae, or caterpillars, are approximately 25-35 millimeters in length and are black or dark brown in color, with yellow or white stripes along their bodies.

The life cycle of the Six-spot Burnet moth begins with the female laying her eggs on the leaves of various host plants, such as Lotus and Trifolium species. The larvae hatch and feed on the host plant, before pupating and emerging as adult moths. The adult moths are active during the day, and are often observed nectaring on flowers.

The Six-spot Burnet moth is known for its ability to sequester and store toxic compounds, known as cyanogenic glycosides, from its host plants. This chemical defense mechanism makes the moth unpalatable to many predators, and contributes to its distinctive coloration, which serves as a warning signal to potential predators.
